Key Arguments: The Bill undermines the right to freedom of speech as per international human rights agreements.
The definition of 'harm' in the Bill is too broad and vague.
The Bill poses a threat to privacy by granting ACMA powers to compel digital platforms to provide information.
There is insufficient accountability and oversight for the potential misuse of censorship powers.
Notable Quotes: If passed, this Bill would undermine the right to freedom of speech, enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
The definition of ‘harm’ is far too broad and vague.
Democracy and the good of Australian society will not be upheld by such broad and vaguely defined powers over the sharing of information.
